title: Use YOLOv7 to Train Dataset
content:
Use YOLOv7 to Train Dataset

Download YOLOv7 Source Code

First, visit the link: https://github.com/WongKinYiu/yolov7 and download the source code, you can also do it on Google Colab, which would be more convenient for those who hate setting the environment.

Set the environment

Suppose you run YOLOv7 on your own computer, you need a environment on which it could run. Here I recommend you to use Anaconda to set your own environment by doing following steps.

conda create -n YOLO python==3.7.4
conda info --envs
conda activate YOLO
pip install -r F:\objectdet\yolov7-main/requirements.txt -i https://pypi.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/simple
pip list

Here we use the tsinghua source web for a better download speed in Asia. You can find the YOLO environment on conda info --envs and check whether your environment have successfully set by looking at the pip list.

There might be a problem that if you follow the instruction by installing all the packages in requirements.txt and you will find out that the PyTorch is a CPU version instead of a GPU version. To run the code more smooth on your computer, you need to download the GPU version of PyTorch by running the following code.

pip install torch==1.8.2+cu111 torchvision==0.9.2+cu111 torchaudio===0.8.2 -f https://download.pytorch.org/whl/lts/1.8/torch_lts.html -i  https://pypi.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/simple

Rewrite the Profile

First go to the file yolov7.yaml on yolov7-main/cfg/training/yolov7.yaml, edit nc.

Then set your own yaml file by looking at the example given in the folder.

Edit the train.py by changing the data path, batch-size, device, workers.

Do remember that if your dataset is coco format, you need to translate it into yolo form.

If there is some error about your dataset, you may try to delete the ache file and then run it again.
